638BD6A1AC9945EDBE016D941F7C0A0F.description: View a variety of artworks from French-Canadian artists, past and present, as an inspiration for talking about and creating art.

C9B0E05153FB4C39957AB1BB29F3B96F.description: Discuss how culture is revealed through First Nations, Métis, and Inuit artworks

370BDD4FAB594B8FA7577A4DBF56B3D3.description: Compare art forms and architecture from ancient Rome to those of modern day

7E1D54CA51164C9191B0EF393B05CF42.description: View artworks and architecture from ancient Rome as an inspiration for creating art

D360269F41F448EF99FA51B87E38DF0E.description: Use visual arts vocabulary when responding to artworks

C50C0C03B32C4157A16BAE7BB0DF620D.description: Demonstrate how to follow artistic protocols and etiquette in various visual arts experiences

BC500EF5534D4BD5AD522020F6B22DA1.description: Describe how artworks are valued in one's life and culture.

3CA390E429B348D3B5BF52EE27C0B736.description: Art forms from New France continue to influence Canadian art today

D8114A7484BD48C8BEFC7EFDD0CB36E3.description: Artworks in New France served a variety of purposes for the diverse groups of people who lived there

215B5F3C00B3407B945F709751DCA4E7.description: The culture of ancient Rome has an influence on modern day artworks

5190484884C345DFB73E72D4CD35F6B6.description: Ancient Roman culture was reflected through artworks and architecture

E87FC718C4094076866DF653E52444B8.description: Artistic communities can be a venue for artistic expression within various cultures

A945EAABF99C46C2AEDE7C15B4A77AC6.description: Artworks are valued differently across cultures throughout history

30FBD56EB65D4005A0551A0AD3E28F06.description: The ceinture fléchée is representative of the cultural heritage of French-Canadians and Métis

C1C92D02984A48EF8ACF020B426143AA.description: The ceinture fléchée is a colourful, patterned sash that emerged as functional clothing from the New France era

2F81430F3BA7481C80955ECF727EF6F7.description: The building of churches in New France was funded by the churches in Europe and often included stained glass altars statues chalices

58E5EE1CD8A849E1AD248F5B36F440B1.description: Art forms used in New France continue to be used today, including sculpting painting metal work with gold and silver woodworking textiles printmaking (lithography) stained glass architecture

DD7E0BB6F78B44BEB2FBF072FB83D0B8.description: Protocols related to how or with whom artworks are created and shared were part of First Nations cultures in New France and continue to hold significant importance today

7AE05F72827641A6BE7470CF71E71731.description: First Nations artworks in New France reflected traditions and beliefs that continue to be honoured and celebrated today by First Nations, Métis, and Inuit.

BC8CB742A7C74E3DB0C9E65D45BBB7B3.description: First Nations cultures in New France had established artistic traditions prior to the arrival of Europeans, including moose hair tufting, quilling, and embroidery work.

DD4A448277FC431F8E28282E05607753.description: Ancient Roman artworks have been found preserved in Pompeii and include murals painted into the plastered walls of buildings (frescoes) images made from tiny pieces of glass or ceramic (mosaics)

B747FF12C8284189AE981A2857DBDD79.description: Ancient Roman pottery was engraved and glazed as a form of decoration, unlike Greek pottery that was painted with designs and images.

7C89F02AB0CC4A16AF7DA58F7724ABF9.description: Roman pottery was a functional form of artwork in ancient Rome and was categorized as follows: Fine ware were formal and decorative pottery pieces. Coarse ware were used for daily purposes such as cooking or food storage

DDEF32F5711A48EEB7148FF312EF82EB.description: The principles of design, including balance, repetition, and harmony, apply to ancient Roman architecture, and can be seen in Basilica of Maxentius Le Pont du Gard Roman Theatre of Orange The Colosseum The Pantheon

5482D7E5EE694FBFA57BD7A0B0371BFE.description: Semicircular arches were so common among Roman architecture that these arches are now known as Roman arches

BA37ED3C937343F294454DF53B594D3F.description: Artworks in ancient Rome were valued for their ability to communicate ways of life and historical events

0AF631446699436EAA7078AA63076FA3.description: Ancient Roman artworks were inspired by the ancient Greeks and other ancient cultures

7FE9399CAAB14F56BAEC1C8E38247BF1.description: The topics or themes expressed through artworks may have a particular significance to the culture, time, and place in which the artworks were created

3869A71C5849436980D0181CA862D779.description: Artistic protocols and etiquette may change based on the community, culture, or presentation of artworks

DC1A3720C7BD4F1A9019D102065D3AE5.description: Using vocabulary related to the elements of art can contribute to discussions about art

954FDCA60797432AB9887632EA38FAB5.description: From historical times to today, cultures value artworks for a variety of reasons, including beauty artistic expression cultural or religious expression representation of a culture or society historical documentation

3E85A5D0B3A0437AB9ED26477812ACD4.description: Students relate visual arts cultures of the past with those of the modern day

7423DEF1C3964968931697D784425FE9.description: Appreciation: Recognizing beauty, goodness, and truth in visual arts can be developed by understanding the complexity and richness of great artworks, the artists who create them, and the historical and cultural contexts from which they originate

8B4E5679FC144DC9A6833ACE8C19E2CB.description: Participate as an artist and as an audience member in a variety of visual arts experiences

6D7811AAE1F7419E8927EB72F1E0DBE8.description: Employ creative processes when representing a message in artworks

A1B06F313E3F478CAC8CADF8FD8B6E90.description: Create a title and description to accompany a work of art

527629E057004F7FBFD13A9672A03005.description: Create a message in artworks through the use of patterns, signs, and symbols

8F20113B47CC439F8E2F96F76305D914.description: Create artworks based on an inspiration

48AA47BAE161447FBA279196908B74D8.description: Explore a variety of ways to create two- and three-dimensional works of art that reflect a message

D104FAAAAFA24FB0AF2C2CF2FD43D3D6.description: Create artworks that feature illusions of depth, distance, or movement

230770460A4C4094A67D6C9F20656909.description: Experiment with how the principles of design can enhance the communication of a message

0755C6C8B52740DAA5D2D1D3692032BE.description: Explore how colour, line, shape, and texture can be combined for a purpose in artworks

DA2E59983F294D96A8C06F34CB63392C.description: Create artworks through experimental and informed artistic choices.

DDF4C66DB45E48FBB081423C9C8B79CE.description: Messages can represent what an artist means to communicate through artworks

938AEF1A15B74239835F471DF66D72B5.description: Viewing art includes receiving and interpreting messages communicated through artworks

7CD77FCCBC7E4C819377447F5655285E.description: A message is at the centre of communication in visual arts

0602586576B349529BF5F28AF7921B76.description: Artists can combine the elements of art in an infinite number of ways to communicate a message

FE4A5A7A424042B0A90E6F94214DDC6D.description: Artists intentionally choose ways to effectively share a message

CE6CFE7308EF4CC9AC360815A5B2A1C0.description: Some topics or themes represented through artworks can be sensitive to some viewers

909241E036E74673BDB28E46CC1D30BA.description: Artworks can be created for an intended audience

8158BCD5067E4227980C0F6F9D4FA92E.description: Messages can evoke different responses from a viewer based on their beliefs, preferences, and feelings

56621770761140C2928487E809997104.description: The message an artist intends to communicate through an artwork can be clarified through the use of titles and descriptions by stepping back to view and reflect on the artwork by discussing the artwork with others

779B3A742940435797E00C49B8C5020C.description: Creative processes can help an artist clarify what they mean to communicate

E3866B2B716540F2B55688ACF4A6ADE8.description: Messages in visual arts can be conveyed through the use of patterns, signs, and symbols.

5A334E38A1604B678E5B2D5010F3F244.description: The circle in First Nations, Métis, or Inuit visual art forms is used to symbolize elements and patterns of the natural world

021E2C675B284E2893D80FBEBFFED849.description: The circle is a symbol that can communicate a message in visual arts, including connection, unity, and cycles.

2E4C39B814AE47999B03BD12627588DB.description: Inspiration for creating a message in visual arts can come from a variety of sources, including other artists or artworks, imagination, or stories

E0CF3E37F45C41B8922057753FF2C8D4.description: Messages can represent a variety of things, including ideas, experiences, and feelings

6E33FAE1971846FC858AFC2C8FD3F4BF.description: Principles of design, including emphasis and contrast, can guide the way that artists use the elements of art to create a message

E561399DCD1A4FE9ACE7CCC34FE64FF8.description: Line can be used to create depth and distance as seen in landscapes that feature middle ground, background, and foreground

FC52FDD36C58459C82829C2D62CB346C.description: The use of colour, tints, and shades, including white and black, can create optical illusions in art when combined with shape, space, and lines

3A411D29A68E4900B34CD5B41CA2EB7A.description: Illusions such as depth, distance, or movement can be created through line-linear or one-point perspective, colour-gradation, texture-hatching, cross-hatching, layering shape-layering, overlapping, changing size and position on the picture plane value-tints and shades

F52E4AB13D5647CE940665C095686211.description: A message in visual arts can convey meaning through the use of illusions in artworks

FA24F66D215C4354B0E3F4A8C0DA19B1.description: New methods of creating art can be revealed through experimentation and unexpected discoveries.

2D114C3A7BB245F6B1A93DFE677C636F.description: Tools, techniques, materials, and media can be used in traditional and non-traditional ways to create a message

C6F8A5DCBBCE40FEAC0AB905DC4898FA.description: Students represent messages through artistic choices related to the elements of art.

F3FF7CDBF8B64AB7903C108B1CFF1A31.description: Creating and Presenting: Ideas can be represented through artworks that draw upon foundational visual arts knowledge

A5BC93F2BDDC49F19D0C0226E58ED351.description: Describe preferences related to texture viewed in artworks

74633C34ABD24472AD2B31E047D707DA.description: Differentiate between actual and simulated texture in artworks and the surrounding environment

42FBC29D931C46B7BEFA392A50FA5A66.description: Use visual arts vocabulary to describe how texture can be used to create an effect in artworks.

3165E4339947466387E14DE004D788EB.description: Apply texture to two- and three-dimensional works of art

F413DEEDDF9242F8B0BDF8142D622077.description: Apply various colour combinations in a composition

AFD2D9E81206485CBE980B568A85EF8D.description: Describe how colour can enhance the visual effect of an artwork.

89655F406425445592DBA442A626F5E9.description: Evaluate the use of primary and secondary colours in various artworks

EE251662E62644AE8831022CB539B178.description: Apply colour to create focus through the use of contrast or emphasis in artworks.

703132CF542B4FF0B28C41CB2FAEEE33.description: Experiment with colour mixing and application of colour

AB2971AE75554801AB1E7A0F88E6B3B7.description: Explore how light can change the way colour is perceived.

E7DDFD908E034310AAEB3B9129189630.description: Examine how artists use colour in a variety of artworks

833363BAD8C74B7BB11D1CC921613F15.description: Texture has characteristics or surface qualities that are unique to an object

BCBAC6113E904D5590407F7E7B673F85.description: Texture can be used to create visual interest or illusions in artworks

EC1FAF1DA6B94311A5270BDD6DC7873E.description: Texture is an element that is present in works of art

D37B34266A1341E594649799AF46A30A.description: Secondary colours are created by mixing two primary colours

A9D5D2E2BD294EB9A613107BB71147DB.description: Colour is an element of art that is categorized into primary colours, including red, blue, and yellow secondary colours, including orange, purple, and green

EE8D95138AD5455AB7AEDCE51223BB90.description: Colour is light that is reflected from an object

0E061D4868074C448D37BD171911B861.description: The texture of an object appeals to some individuals but not to others.

637DC22F9A684A639A61F3E542B08B0A.description: Texture exists on natural and manufactured objects.

323D8781751A49ECAC88CB66B77ADC87.description: Simulated texture gives the impression of how something would feel when touched, as seen in Albrecht Dürer, Young Hare, c. 1502

20E4BB93E6884A098E0944F42BE1AE53.description: Characteristics of texture can be described using words, including wrinkled or smooth soft or rough furry or coarse

17F1019117604777B1A100D2A80714DC.description: Actual texture is how an object feels when touched

D47521EE16F346259DE2593C96D4B277.description: Examples of texture in various artworks can include Claude Monet, Tulip Field in Holland, c. 1886 Justin Gaffrey, Seascapes Collection, c. 2018-2020 Mary Pratt, Red Currant Jelly, c. 1972 Vincent van Gogh, Self-Portrait, c. 1889

6CF0479ABA1047BD8CD5185FE5740838.description: Texture can be applied to two- and three-dimensional works of art as seen in Justin Gaffrey, Seascapes Collection, c. 2018-2020 The Ife Head, Yoruba, c. 13th century CE

85126FB51D9041EBB418718E7A9D3C45.description: Paint can be applied either thick or thin to create a desired textural effect

12DA499352444AF3A36CE948B41F3F1D.description: Hatching and cross-hatching can create texture through the use of line

35E7363DF34B4842B50E030DCC83B8B3.description: Tools, techniques, materials, and media can be used and combined to create texture.

077E39B8F2724C13B3F19CA12CABBE56.description: Texture can be created by layering or combining line, shape, and colour

C131CCA87299429589CAF23DA1309BE8.description: Colour can be used to create emphasis, focal points, and contrast, as seen in Diego Rivera, La Piñata, n.d

8792B8A0B52B437D86E85E2C56EEF560.description: The use of secondary colours in artworks can be seen in Helen Frankenthaler, Blue Atmosphere, c. 1963 Mark Rothko, Red, Orange, Tan and Purple, c. 1954 Paul Gauguin, Tahitian Landscape, c. 1892

3E517E770B514BD695CF04E2BCBF9F25.description: The proportion of colour used when mixing a new colour can affect the resulting colour.

9F6293DAFE5E40B89022649FA14B77CC.description: Many variations of colours can be created by mixing colours

57C8F88C1B8B43038DB66BA2AD027156.description: The use of light in artworks can be seen in Elioth Gruner, Spring Frost, 1919 James Chapin, Ruby Green Singing, c. 1928 Johannes Vermeer, The Milkmaid, c. 1660

94F9088046C54B08905B766C798F50F4.description: The visible spectrum includes the colours red orange yellow green blue indigo violet

9188A68D43724FB79D9588B83E0DB702.description: Hue is the generic name for a colour and defines the purest state of a colour within the visible spectrum

77356F22D7804983BF4EFB96874AC11E.description: Colour can be detected as part of the visible spectrum, as seen in rainbows and prisms.

0E5BA608C7B24EA98D22C01F1AACE3A0.description: Colour can seem to change in value when light is varied

065981EC71D34F1D8DD4D1589B99D435.description: Colour is a visual response to wavelengths of light

CE385A809A4D42F98DBA2E32CA611A8B.description: Students examine various ways in which texture can be represented in artworks.

27C3DDFC79D344969413E330555C380F.description: Students analyze colour as an element of art.

0D14CC52A56B4E1AB0BB028829C87ECC.description: Foundational Elements and Principles: Visual arts literacy is developed through knowledge and application of foundational elements and principles
